Problem:
Consider a system in which the temperature distribution \\( u(x,t) \\) in a rod is governed by the heat equation \\( u_t = k u_{xx} \\), where \\( k \\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. We investigate what happens when a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) is applied on the initial temperature distribution, and later an inverse Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}^{-1} \\) is used.

If the initial temperature distribution \\( u(x,0) \\) is mapped by a Fourier transform and then allowed to evolve according to the heat equation, will the temperature distribution at any time \\( t \\) be exactly representable by applying the inverse Fourier transform to the evolved transform?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of the initial condition, followed by an analytical solution of the transformed heat equation and an inverse Fourier transform, will correctly reproduce the time-evolved temperature distribution. The linear nature of both the Fourier transform and the heat equation preserves the transformation sequence.
